Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I was in the middle of trimming Mrs. Lee’s fringe when my phone buzzed with a message from my mom: “Don’t forget, family dinner at 6. Grandma’s expecting you to help with the dumplings.” I glanced at the clock—5:45. Mrs. Lee, always cheerful, smiled at me in the mirror. “Could you just take a little more off the front? I trust you.” I knew she had a big event tonight and wanted to look her best. My hands hesitated, scissors poised. If I rushed, I might mess up her hair, but if I took my time, I’d be late for dinner, and Grandma would be disappointed. My family always said, “Traditions keep us together,” and missing dinner would let them down. But as a hairdresser, my clients expect my full attention and care. I felt the pressure building in my chest, torn between the warmth of family expectations and the pride I took in my work. I looked at Mrs. Lee’s hopeful eyes, then at the message from my mom, and felt the weight of both worlds pressing in.
